Review Recent progress on discovery and properties prediction of energy materials: Simple machine learning meets complex quantum chemistry Yongqiang Kang a b ⁎ Lejing Li c Baohua Li a ⁎ a Tsinghua Shenzhen International Graduate School, Tsinghua University, Shenzhen 518055, Guangdong, China Tsinghua Shenzhen International Graduate School Tsinghua University Shenzhen 518055 Guangdong China Tsinghua Shenzhen International Graduate School, Tsinghua University, Shenzhen 518055, Guangdong, China b School of Materials Science and Engineering, Tsinghua University, Beijing 100081, China School of Materials Science and Engineering Tsinghua University Beijing 100081 China School of Materials Science and Engineering, Tsinghua University, Beijing 100081, China c Department of Chemistry, The Chinese University of Hong Kong, Hong Kong 999077, China Department of Chemistry The Chinese University of Hong Kong Hong Kong 999077 China Department of Chemistry, The Chinese University of Hong Kong, Hong Kong 999077, China ⁎ Corresponding authors at: Tsinghua Shenzhen International Graduate School, Tsinghua University, Shenzhen 518055, Guangdong, China (Y. Kang) Tsinghua Shenzhen International Graduate School Tsinghua University Shenzhen 518055 Guangdong China Graphical abstract The emergence of artificial intelligence, especially machine learning algorithms, has accelerated the development of computational materials science based on quantum chemistry, which is conducive to the exploration and understanding of new energy materials. In nature, the properties of matter are ultimately governed by the electronic structures. Quantum chemistry (QC) at electronic level matches well with a few simple physical assumptions in solving simple problems. To date, machine learning (ML) algorithm has been migrated to this field to simplify calculations and improve fidelity. This review introduces the basic information on universal electron structures of emerging energy materials and ML algorithms involved in the prediction of material properties. Then, the structure-property relationships based on ML algorithm and QC theory are reviewed. Especially, the summary of recently reported applications on classifying crystal structure, modeling electronic structure, optimizing experimental method, and predicting performance is provided. Last, an outlook on ML assisted QC calculation towards identifying emerging energy materials is also presented. Keywords Energy materials Quantum chemistry Machine learning Structure-property relationship 1 Introduction Throughout human history, the abundance of energy material associated with all kinds of human production activities. To date, excessive energy consumptions were not adapted to the current needs for a sustainable development. Energy materials are materials used in energy harvesting, storage and conversion filed such as photovoltaics, batteries, fuel cells and photo(electro)catalysis, etc. Energy materials including intermetallic alloys, metal/covalent–organic frameworks, carbon materials, perovskite and spinel materials play an important role in global economic development [1–5]. For instance, as an efficient ammonia synthesis materials, iron(Fe)-based catalysts invented in the early 20th century have promoted food production, which feeds billions of people [6–8]. Recent electroreduction of N2 by catalysts is promising to produce ammonia in a more cost-effective way. Therefore, finding green energy materials is highly desired but remains a challenge to cut carbon emissions, control environmental pollution, and reduce waste [9,10]. In the last two decades, the number of academic papers focused on the research and innovation of “energy materials” witness an exponential growth (Fig. 1 a) [11]. Under such a rapid growth rate of discovering new materials, people can hardly point out useful information directly and identify promising materials without optimized performance. Chemists sought for desired materials or material preparation methods usually rely on trial and error method, which based on numerous failed experiments and by-products [12,13]. Recently, combinatorial quantum chemistry (QC) and high-throughput screening are expected to bridge the gap [14,15]. Theory calculations can not only confirm the reliability of data but predict untried methods. For example, the density functional theory (DFT) calculations of noble metals predicted the volcano plot for oxygen reduction reaction, which accelerates the investigation into fuel cell related cathode materials [16,17]. On the other hand, improvements in artificial algorithmic provide a new window to find insights or make fast predictions of target properties by mining from big data. As for computational materials science, the machine learning (ML) techniques help to reduce the amount of calculation, and speed up the exploration of energy materials (Fig. 1b). Recently, ML assisted high-throughput screening for crystal structure prediction [18–20], electronic characteristics [21,22], experimental procedures [23] and materials performance searches [24] are found to be reasonable and applicable (Fig. 1c). At present, the developed ML techniques accelerate the identification of energy materials. These contributions include the discovery and the optimization of energy materials [24], determination of the structure–property relationship [25], and modeling of reactive coordinates [26], etc. For instance, Butler et al. [27] summarized the applications of ML algorithms including dataset, model and data-mining tools for molecules and materials. They believe the front direction lies in smaller dataset, simpler descriptor, higher fidelity and more scientific laws. Graser et al. highlights ML tools for crystal structure predictions [18], and Li et al. summarized cases of artificial neural network (ANN) methods for catalyst materials [28]. Although some of the contributions have been summarized before [18,27–34], latest works especially for new applications are not included. These reviews always focus on ML algorithms for specific filed or applications, whereas the structure-property relationship of these materials is not clearly indicated and discussed. Currently, it is necessary to figure out the key points for energy materials development. The key points are: (1) The effect of electronic properties on materials properties. Especially for computer scientists, they inevitably need to understand the basic electronic structures and QC. (2) The critical issues of material science. For computational materials science, the experiential details are not always fully considered but often filtered to simplify the model. (3) The calculation principle, advantages and disadvantages of ML models. For material scientists, they must be absolutely aware of the accuracy of the calculation results. Considering the rapid development of ML, it is necessary to build an integrated system of ML programs. However, interdisciplinary integration is a hash task. For energy materials screening, the comprehensive description of ML is firstly needed when designing for special purpose of ML. Therefore, an updated review is beneficial to outline the cutting-edge of ML assisted energy materials discovery. Since the complexity of quantum chemistry (QC) in materials science, especially in the energy materials filed, machine learning (ML) method is necessary to be introduced to save time and improve accuracy. Shi et al. [35] summarizes the applications of machine learning technology in the field of material development: (1) Macro and micro-performance predictions, such as glass transition temperature [36,37], metal corrosion behavior, lattice constant and lithium-ion diffusion mechanism. (2) Property of predicted materials, such as material structure and performance. (3) Other aspects of the application, such as battery performance monitoring [38]. (4) Common problems of ML algorithms. Herein we not only declare the necessity of ML, but also summarize the effective applications in QC-related areas. Our review focuses on the energy materials towards energy harvesting, storage and conversion. We mainly highlight the properties of strong electron correlation based on quantum chemistry, such as electronic structure and electronic transport. We also highlight the basic methods of ML and discuss various examples where ML technique is employed for state-of-the-art materials research. We will review the intrinsic electronic structures of energy materials, and the screw out the fundamental degrees of freedom (orbital, spin, lattice and charge) is the future direction, which is in prospect of cutting-edge techniques. More importantly, establishing the connection between quantum chemistry theory and machine learning algorithm, is the core of this review. We finally conclude the challenges and prospects to carry forward in this field. 2 Quantum chemistry reveals the electronic structure It is widely known that the discovery of the Schrödinger equation and its application into the hydrogen atom mark the birth of quantum chemistry (QC). By using QC, physicists have achieved great success in describing simple microphysics. Considering the complex chemical reactions, QC appears deficient in determining the chemical behavior of an atom [15]. Even though, calculations can provide detailed thermodynamics and kinetics information, such as Gibbs free energy, binding energy [39], or energy band [40]. For heterogeneous catalysis, QC helps to screen ideal catalyst, reveal surface active sites and understand structure-property relations [41]. The electronic structure of materials is the cornerstone of QC theory [14]. Briefly, understanding the position of free electrons in the space, describing the motion trajectory of electron, ruling electron order of filling orbitals, and discovering the role of electrons in chemical bonds are the key tasks for electronic structure theory. “Quantized” electrons move around the nucleus of an atom in different orbitals, which depends on the nuclear charge and interaction of electron-nucleus. As for chemically bonded atoms, the electronic orbitals are splitting into molecular orbitals (MO) with separated energy levels. In solid-state physics, it is not the isolated atom but crystalline materials formed by a large number of atoms. The individual energy levels of neighboring atoms overlap with continuous bands. In order to describe the bonding interactions between the center transition metals and surrounding ligands, crystal field theory (CFT) is found. The d orbit of the central atom is originally five-fold degenerate, but orbital energy levels split when ligands approaches. The interaction is considered to be static electricity; therefore, the distribution of energy levels can be calculated by surrounding ligands. The CFT cannot explain the covalent bonding between center transition metals and surrounding ligands. The MO theory can be extended to the covalent bonding of center atom and ligand, where the covalent bonding is different from static electric, and this modified CFT also called ligand field theory. The d-band center, as an important theory for bonding and reactivity of transition metals is adopted and applied widely in theoretical calculation [42]. B. Hammer & J. K. Norskov stressed the d-band shape, in other words, the position of d-band center determined by the width of d-band which significantly relies on the coordination number of metal site [43,44]. Even though, several results proved that d-band center is inadequate for demonstrating the catalytic activity of magnetically polarized transition metals [45], and also the activity of Pt-core–Pd-shell nanoparticles [46]. These observations reveal the real chemical systems are more complicated than the simple QC calculations. Linear free energy relationships (LFERs) and volcano plots also play important role in catalyst filed, especially in electrochemical reactions. Balandin first discussed the volcano plots in 1970s [47,48]. Up to date, researchers have studied various volcano plots of surface catalytic reactions based on transition metals. For example, by investigating the interaction of HCOOH vapors with W, Rootsaert and Sachtler firstly reported catalytic dehydrogenation of HCOOH vapor on W [49]. This discovery has a general relationship and has been extended to other metal catalysts. Mark A. Barteau found an exception to the LFERs of transition metal surfaces, i.e. Group VIII and IB metals show a different relationship between the decomposition of formate and methoxide intermediates [50]. Towards the progress of theoretical calculation, Norskov et al. has developed linear scaling relationships and volcano plot for hydrogen-containing molecules on transition metal oxide, sulfide, and nitride surfaces [51–53]. To date, researchers are focusing on new reactions and systems to breaking scaling relations [54,55]. Generally, QC methods are based on the Hartree-Fock method (Fig. 2 ). Post-Hartree-Fock methods including MP2, MP4, CCSD(T), promoted the progress of QC methods. Developed methods including ab initio methods, semi-empirical methods, and density functional theory (DFT) based on quantum mechanics are commonly recognized methods. Since post-HF methods are usually used to calculate electric properties of small sets of molecular and clusters. DFT instead of molecular-orbital method is normally used in solid-state physics especially for cases involving many symmetrical structures. Yet QC has brought us basic information on solid-state material, these results still rely on the ideal model based on simple hypothesis. In real conditions, the reaction process is quite complicated. The computational complexity of quantum chemistry limits the simulation of real systems [56–58]. The innovations in computer science and the improvements to artificial intelligent algorithm brings opportunity to QC simulation. 3 Machine learning algorithm accelerates material design The earliest application of machine learning (ML) in material development can be traced back to the last century [41,59]. The limitation of data and hardware prohibited the ML techniques at that time [60]. Nowadays artificial intelligence algorithms become more convenient and enable high-throughput screening. As an important branch of artificial intelligence, ML focuses on how computer programs improve their performance automatically based on data mining. In other words, using known data, the computer can automatically predict or discover unknowns under the guidance of optimized algorithms (Fig. 2), such as experimental parameters, information, and statistical results. A key task so far has been to improve models to simulate more complex situations, such as electrochemical reactions, molecule adsorption sites, harsh service conditions [12,61,62]. Machine learning is similar to human learning [63], except that human intelligence relies on the brain, while machine learning relies on computer algorithms [64]. In general, human learning ability can be trained by the accumulation of social experience. As for ML, computers can be regarded as scientific instrument that output desired results based on information entered. The progress of ML lies in timely judgment and decision- making based on designed rules, science laws, and accumulated experience. Similarly, ML can be separated into three parts: input, learning, and output. In the input part, computers recognize and store huge amounts of training data for specific cases. Intrinsic relationships and laws are summarized in the learning part. The output part is expected to predict and estimates new problems of the laws learned. To some extent, ML is similar process to human learning, i.e. computer mimicking the behavior of the human brain. The solution is finding out a kind of algorithms or a series of algorithms which can output more credible results in the shortest time. Currently, there are many kinds of ML algorithms (summarized in Fig. 3), including the supervised learning, unsupervised learning, and reinforcement model [1,27,63,65–67]. Supervised learning is characterized by features and labels. Even if the data is unlabeled, the relationship between learning features and labels can be used to determine the label. Unsupervised learning means the algorithms are not enable to label data, which can be divided into several categories—clustering by the internal relationship and similarity [68]. And reinforcement learning solves the current problems through continuous reward and punishment, and optimized strategy can be obtained after constantly strengthen operations [14,69–73]. As the specific ML methods have introduced and summarized elsewhere, we will not repeat the details of each method. Commonly used algorithms include naive bayes, nearest neighbor estimators, decision tree and random forest [74], support vector machine, lifting algorithm, EM algorithm, neural network, K-means clustering, Apriori algorithm and so on. Among them, the artificial neural network (ANN) has been widely applied to the research of energy materials, especially in catalysts screening [28]. Also, some useful databases accelerate the high-value results output [75]. Nevertheless, cost problems still obstacle the determination of large scale datasets [76]. 4 Tetrahedral structure-property relationship In the field of traditional material science, the structure-preparation-property-performance tetrahedral relationship is a tried and true principle [77]. Similarly, chemists usually concern more about the reaction mechanism beyond materials preparation, as well as the reaction progresses under operando conditions (Fig. 4 a). To characterize the physicochemical properties of reactants is a requisite. Therefore, from the chemistry perspective, there should be a preparation-characterization-property-mechanism tetrahedral relationship. Understanding four fundamental degrees of freedom (orbital, spin, lattice and charge) plays a critical role in the electronic property [78]. Here we take the order-disorder transformation of PtFe nanoparticle (NPs) as an example to illustrate the relationship. PtFe NPs as magnetic recording materials and catalysts have attracted much attentions [79]. There is a disorder-order phase transformation during the preparation of PtFe NPs. Typically, a phase transformation from fcc A1-PtFe to fct L10-PtFe occurs for PtFe NPs with diameter of ~4 nm during under ~550 °C annealing (Fig. 4b). Annealed L10-PtFe NPs show larger coercivity compared to plasma treated A1-PtFe NPs (Fig. 4c) [80]. This phase transformation can be deciphered by magnetic properties of nanoparticles such as orbital magnetic moment and spin magnetic moment. L10-PtFe NPs with shorter Pt-Pt distance hereby show enhancement oxygen reduction reaction performance (Fig. 4d) [81]. The quantum mechanics/molecular mechanics (QM − MM) simulations were performed to uncover the difference of Pt-O binding energies (Fig. 4e, f) [82]. The calculation result indicates that the oxygen adsorption energy of L10-PtFe NPs is closer to the optimal value (0.20 eV) of the volcano plot, which follows the Sabatier principle. Therefore, strategies to obtain ordered L10 phase catalysts needs further exploration. Observing the phase transformation in the atomic level is an intriguing process. The ordered phase (L10 and L12) was first formed at the surface of particles during annealing (Fig. 4g) [83]. The precise 3D reconstruction of more than 20,000 single atoms of a PtFe NPs by atomic electron tomography extends the understanding of materials into more fundamental degrees of freedom (e.g. atomic magnetic moments or magnetocrystalline anisotropy energy) (Fig. 4h) [84]. “There's plenty of room at the bottom.” Obviously, it takes so much effort to understand a phenomenon at the atomic scale, let alone a more general section (more particles or more than one degree of freedom). To establish the strongly correlated connection between spin and orbit in solids, further to understand the structure-activity relationship of energy materials, it is absolutely necessary to use machine learning algorithms in quantum chemistry techniques. Besides decoding the fundamental relationships behinds structure and properties, the breakthrough of technologies, including synchrotron radiation [85], neutron diffraction [86], spherical aberration corrected scanning transmission electron microscope [87], and so on, also promote the research and development of energy materials. 5 Applications of machine learning for the development of energy materials At present, ML has been applied to the design and optimization of energy materials, including high-temperature alloys [88], perovskites for solar cells [89], lithium-ion battery materials [90,91], catalytic materials [92], phosphors [93], carbon-based supercapacitors [94], and van der Waals (vdW) heterostructures [95] etc. In addition to accelerating the development of energy materials, ML can also optimize the QC calculation methods. Even tremendous progress has been realized, there is no universal method for different systems (such as electride [96,97], MXenes [98,99]) till now. Here, some selected examples are discussed analyze the role of ML in the field of energy materials. For convenience, this part is divided into four main aspects: Modeling electronic structure, classifying crystal structure, optimizing experimental methods, and predicting performance. 5.1 Modeling electronic structure-(potential energy, band energy, band gap and density functionals) Determining the electronic structure of materials is the premise of understanding their performance. Perovskite oxide family is regard as promising catalysts for several energy conversions including water splitting [100,101], nitrogen oxides reduction [102], solar cells [103] and carbon dioxide captures [104]. Yang et al. [105] highlight that ML will provide upcoming opportunities to high-throughput DFT calculations, and the prediction of activity and physical performance (Fig. 5 a). ML-assisted molecular dynamics and high-throughput screening experiments are combined to explore perovskite materials efficiently. In addition, by comparing the neural network predictions with recalculated DFT energies of bulk silicon, Behler and Parrinello [53] found each metate of the potential matches well. Then, they improved neural network potentials methods compared with DFT potential energy for calculation of bcc copper at 500 K, which reaction paths not influence on the fidelity and saving to calculate cost (Fig. 5b) [106]. Besides the potential energy, the precise band gap of metal surface is crucial criteria for photo(electro)catalyst and other semiconductors. High-fidelity bandgap by QC calculation is a time-consuming task, which is not practical in high throughput research. Yet the statistical learning method based on informatics may be a promising choice. Pilania and collaborators [107] present a systematic engineering method and a powerful learning framework for bandgap prediction of the double perovskites. After evaluating more than 1.2 million features, they concluded that the lowest occupied Kohn-Sham level and the elemental electronegativity of the perovskite atoms are the most important and accurate predictors (Fig. 5c). Inspired by Phillips’s ionicity theory of solid-state physics, Liang et al. [108] demonstrated a least absolute shrinkage and selection operator to predict the band energy and band gap. This method shows high accuracy and can be further extended to other databases (Fig. 5d, e). This work definitely resolves the few-shot problem, while the previous methods only applied to the database used for training. Therefore, Smith et al. [109] introduced a modified Behler-Parrinello (BP) method, so called accurate neural network engine for molecular energies. They use atomic environment vectors to represent molecules in complex chemical environments, which including organic molecules, e.g. a benzene ring, alkenes, functional groups, etc. Besides, Brian Kolb and collaborators [110] extended BP method to the reaction system, including the scattering of molecules and/or dissociation from metal surfaces. Burke, one of the developers of PBE stands, reported a ML-produced functional [111]. That so-called ML approximation (MLA) achieves the more accurate of kinetic energy than that of any other approximation (Fig. 5f). Since it is data-driven by training sets, the MLA requires without much prior knowledge of physics. However, based on collection plot of test set and the new data set, the chemical accuracy of MLA stands at left of the interpolation (Fig. 5g). Even the accuracy could be improved by human correction, it is difficult to find out the source of error because of the self-training process. 5.2 Classifying crystal structure-(recognition of crystal, deformation and segregation) Besides perovskites and phosphors, ML tools can identify the lattice symmetry of unknown materials. Ziletti et al. [112] used advanced ML to simulate the symmetry of defective structures. They simulate the crystal more than 100,000 crystal structures by calculating the diffraction image through a deep learning neural network model. More importantly, this classical algorithm is also applicable to crystal structure with rich defects (even the defect concentration is up to 40%). Thus it is considered a reliable tool for crystal symmetry recognition and crystal classification. For instance, with the help of simulate approaches, the phase transition from body-centered-cubic to simple cubic (bcc-to-sc) structure was predicted. When the moving number of center atom of bcc increased to 75% percentage, the defective structure probably changes into sc structure (Fig. 6 a, b). Rare-earth doped inorganic phosphors are the key to solid-state lighting [113–115]. Traditionally, new phosphor was prepared by solid state reaction [115]. Zhuo and coworkers [93] demonstrated that the Debye temperature of crystal structure of phosphors can be predicted by combining the support vector machine regression model with the high-throughput DFT calculation, where the Debye temperature is the represent the quantum yield of photoluminescence. NaBaB9O15:Eu2+ is selected by screening compounds with highest Debye temperature and largest band gap (Fig. 6c–f). Then NaBaB9O15:Eu2+ phosphor was synthesized by solid state sintering, showing a high (95%) quantum yield and satisfied thermal stability. Instead of trial and error method, ML supported vector machine regression model is beneficial to the discovery of suitable energy materials. The formation, movement and disappearance of crystal defect have an important impact on the activity and stability of energy materials [116,117]. For microcrystals, different samples may present different stress-strain curves, which possess a challenge to the study of plastic deformation of crystals. Salmenjoki et al. [118] discussed this purely random phenomenon and proposed that the predictability of deformation is possible. They used regression neural networks and support vector machines to learn the changes in strain and crystal size during plastic deformation. By carrying out dynamics simulation on discrete dislocation data, ML model can predict the mapping of existing dislocation motions and yield strain (Fig. 7 a). This predictive model suggested larger systems are easier to be predicted (Fig. 7b). This might because that the probability of dislocation motions in larger systems is greater to enable predictability of deformation. Defects not only affect structural transition, but also affect dislocation motions. Furthermore, defects in solute grain boundary (GB) can lead to atomic segregation [120,121]. Even solute atoms in millions of host atoms can cause qualitative change of mechanical properties. In other words, the segregation concept is atomic magnitude order of the solute. However, many defect configurations need strictly approximate models. Huber et al. [119] demonstrated that ML descriptors can accurately predict the segregation energy distribution and isotherm segregation (Fig. 7c) with the aid of high-throughput study and 1 million segregation energy dataset. The diagram shows the energy distribution of magnesium atoms at different GB positions in place of the selected boundary on the polar plot. This ML tool accurately determines the relationship between GB segregation and GB energy, thus providing a new set of identifying advanced material. 5.3 Predicting performance-(catalytic property of CO2 fixation and methanol electro-oxidation, lifetime of lithium-ion batteries) Carbon dioxide (CO2) fixation not only mitigates the greenhouse effect but also converts CO2 into value-added chemicals. In order to systematically study the solubility of CO2 in sodium phosphate solution, Li et al. explored the intrinsic trend of CO2 solubility by data-mining [122,123]. Using generalized regression neural network (GRNN) algorithm, one can quantify the type and concentration of mixed solutions. Besides, by means of GRNN algorithm, the relationship between CO2 solubility and others experimental conditions can be discovered, and the general trend of CO2 solubility in mixed solutions can also be predicted. In a wide range of energy materials, Xin et al. [124] proposed a ML augmented chemisorption model that can quickly predict the surface reactivity of alloys. Firstly, as a biologically inspired learning algorithms, after trained through a set of ab initio adsorption energy from an ideal bimetallic surface, ANN can predict *CO adsorbates on a multimetallic surface with an error of ~0.1 eV. Then screening of high-throughput catalysts greatly relies on the scaling relationships between adsorption energy of adsorbates. For example, by using scaling relations and ANN learning algorithms, the electrochemical reduction of carbon dioxide (CO2RR) to the C2 products was realized by {100}-terminated multimetallic alloys. Besides, the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) must be taken into consideration when considering CO2RR, because of the lower overpotential of HER than that of CO2RR. Therefore, Tran & Ulissi [25] reported a systemic and automatic screening method to guide DFT calculation, thereby predicting the CO2RR electrocatalytic activity. They demonstrated the screening results of various alloys formed by 31 different elements, and the filter range included 50% d-block elements and 33% p-block elements (Fig. 8 a). So far, this method has identified 131 surfaces for CO2RR in 54 alloys after calculating 42,785 adsorption energy and 258 surfaces for hydrogen generation in 102 alloys. Even though there still are prediction errors (ca. 0.1 eV) when using feedforward ANN model to practical catalyst identification [124], the calculation results did not match polycrystalline experiments well even high-throughput DFT workflow optimized ANN model [25]. This mainly because the active adsorption sites in these models lie in precise crystal surface. Considering that the reactivity of these active sites is related to its electronic properties, the created surface structure of the model is different from the surface of cluster catalysts in experimental cases. The weak binding site of the cluster with low coordination number may also be an active site for reactions. These neglected points as drawbacks of the CO2RR volcano model still remain. Also, these models did not address other important issues of catalysis, such as stability or economy. Bimetallic catalyst is one of the most promising CO2RR catalysts according to modern QC calculation. Tracing active sites on polycrystalline samples is a profound work and requires many works on experimental and theoretical calculations [126,127]. Basically, hundreds of active sites on stable low-index facets of bimetallic crystals represent the possible active sites. Norskov and collaborators [24] used a neural network based model to reduce the amount of DFT calculations and calculated the CO2RR on nickel-gallium bimetallic surface. The results showed that the activity for most surfaces is the same as that of the nickel surfaces, but there are a few exposed nickel sites with good on-top CO configuration (Fig. 8b). This predictive ML model followed the rules of facet reactivity and surface active sites paves a new way to find out promising catalysts. As above mentioned, a new fingerprint descriptor based on the chemical adsorption theory has been adopted in optimizing parameters of ANN. As popular energy materials, bimetallic catalysts have found important applications for methanol fuel cells [128]. Xin et al. [125] used electrochemical methanol oxidation as the model reaction to draw a volcanic activity map (see Fig. 8c). Combined with the free energy correction table, they provided a linear scaling relationship between *CO with carbon-bonding species and *OH with oxygen-bonding species. After that, they established an ML model trained by existing ~1000 ideal alloy surface database. This database can capture the complex and nonlinear adsorption/metal interaction with ~0.2 eV RMSE errors (Fig. 8d). Lithiated and delithiated process in cathode materials induce volume changes, further affecting the lifetime of lithium-ion batteries. In order to reveal the relationship between structural characteristics and volume changes in the electrochemical process, by using partial least squares (PLS) regression, Chen et al. predicted structural distortion of Li-O and X-O polyhedral (Fig. 9 a) [129]. X represents 14 metal elements (Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Nb, Mo, Ru, Rh, Pd, Ta, Ir) that involved in oxide cathodes. Compared to DFT calculations, the regression results can well predict the major parameters of volume change. However, predicting variables in the more complicated system is ongoing. It is challenging but vital to predict the lifetime of lithium-ion batteries due to the complex mechanisms of capacity degradation. Braatz et al. [130] developed a new model with the help of ML tools to predict the lifetime of batteries through the early-cycle data (Fig. 9b–d). Namely, the predicting based on first 100 cycles only achieves errors of 9.1%, even though the entire lifetime of a battery normally shows a nonlinear degradation. Compared to traditional power and capacity loss forecasting models, the data-driven model uses high-rate discharge voltage curves without considering the relevant physicochemical knowledge of battery degradation. Since this model was carried out in the commercial lithium iron phosphate (LFP)-graphite battery, the broad applications and model robustness in the relevant system to be further tested. 5.4 Optimizing experimental method-(two-dimensional (2D) and carbon-based materials) Since the discovery of graphene earned the Nobel Prize in 2010, Graphdiyne (GDY) and other two-dimensional materials have started an upsurge in energy materials science [131,132]. A simple two-dimensional (2D) material identification criterion is needed when comparing the experimental lattice constants with DFT computed lattice constants [133]. Naturally, there are always two lattice constant differences greater than or equal to 5% in 2D materials. New materials that meet both the lattice difference and the stripping energy criterion will be considered as 2D materials. Choudhary and coworkers [134] discovered that there are at least 1356 2D materials, and these predicted materials not only meet the lattice difference but also match the exfoliation energy criterion. Further experimental evidences are needed for all systems predicted by the simple criterions. Thickness is also an important factor when identifying 2D materials. Recently, a method combined Fresnel law with ML was proposed to identify the layer thickness of 2D materials [135]. By using K-mean clustering and K-nearest neighbor ML algorithm, the optical images of 2D materials are predictively analyzed. This algorithm can provide a fast and accurate descriptor for properties of 2D materials (Fig. 10 ). The van der Waals (vdW) heterostructures as a promising 2D materials [136] include transition metal sulfides (MoS2, WS2, NbS2 and ReS2, etc), transition metal selenides (MoSe2, NbSe2, WSe2 and NbSe2, etc), transition metal antimonides (NiSb2, TiSb2 and FeSb2, etc) and transition metal tellurides (WTe2, HfTe2 and NbTe2, etc). To explore the structural and electronic properties of all possible hybrid 2D materials, Ford and coworkers [95] predicted the interlayer distance and band gap of these bilayers by ML method. Their results are more effective than DFT calculations, also are beneficial to avoid synthesizing useless heterostructures. TiO2 and MnO2 are widely used in energy conversion and storage fields, such as photocatalysis. Olivetti et al. devoted to screening the synthesis of these materials from published literature [137]. A variational autoencoder (VAE) neural network was developed to generate a parameter set of SrTiO3 synthesis. The VAE framework visually revealed the potential driving factors of TiO2 synthesis, and found the intercalation effects of selected ions during the synthesis of different MnO2 phases. This VAE approach can screen optimized synthetic parameters, identify the formation and influence factor of different phases, as well as the relationship between material crystal phase and intercalated ions. Nevertheless, direct factors of synthesis methods for inorganic materials are still awaiting. Besides metal oxide catalysts, carbon materials have been at the forefront of energy materials researches [138]. Carbon materials are widely used as electrode materials in energy storage devices such as supercapacitors and lithium-ion batteries [139]. For example, Zhu et al. [94] used ANN method to predict the capacitance of carbon materials in the supercapacitor field. In order to train the model, they extracted the data from over 1000 pieces of literatures related to supercapacitors. Finally, five parameters, including specific surface area, calculated pore size, I D/I G ratio, N doping level and voltage window, were selected to train the ML model, followed by the performances of multiple selected carbon-based materials were predicted. ANN shows greater potential than linear regression and Lasso in discovering advanced carbon material for supercapacitors (Fig. 11 a and b). Graphene also has been attracted much attention, Fernandez et al. [140,141] calculated the band gap (E G) energy, the ionization potential (E I) energy, the Fermi level (E F) energy, and the electron affinity (E A) energy of graphene nanoflakes by ML modeling. For example, the model accelerated the reasonable design of functional graphene through predicting the energy gap of graphene nanoflakes (Fig. 11c). The ML model accurately calculated ca. 80% electronic properties of graphene in the training set, efficiently described structures–electronic relationships of graphene solely. Even the result showed a high confidence level, the calculation deviation was still inevitable. If the data point is farther away from the mean, the deviation in the dataset becomes greater. However, these deviations may result from intrinsic defects or experimental errors of materials, or cause by the limitation of one specific model that is not suitable for multiscale materials [142]. Therefore, under different classifications, it is more important to find out the right tolerance parameters to meet the minimum deviations from the specific structures. 6 Current challenges Challenging the holy grail of-how to build a good ML model from limited data is crucial. Data diversity of scales is one of the most important aspects. With the increasing proliferation of large-scale data, the training program must take the diversity scales of data into consideration. Besides, large-scale data sets of material properties are necessary and urgent to be optimized. The material genome initiative is being developed and applied to numerous domains, such as energy and environment, medicine and health, military and aerospace field. These data are gradually extended to ML models, which has contributed a lot to the recent developments of energy materials. Meanwhile, to match the models well, one needs both the proficient skills on ML algorithm and the deep understanding of the applied field. For calculators, developing effective rules to search hyperparameter for algorithms optimization, or learning more complexity knowledge for searching hyperparameters might be time consuming and inefficient. Meanwhile, choosing appropriate hyperparameters is a harsh work to do so. A compromise way might be model complexity. Undeniably, however, such costly process cannot maximize throughput and minimize errors. It is still challenging but promising to predict computation with the rise of deep learning. In order to obtain results of high confidence, it is necessary to verify and validate the ML models. Data scientists for materials science have successfully simulated and predicted many new materials for a specific area. However, due to the limitations of experimental conditions and synthesis methods, the development of many ideal materials lags behind the calculation results. To solve this problem, an improved cross-validation method (i.e. k-fold cross validation) is proposed, which provides a useful estimation of the predictive performance of models. For instance, Xiong et al. [22] developed a k-fold cross validation model to predict material properties through ML. They have addressed the limitation of the traditional k-fold cross-validation method of new evaluation methods. By changing the property value of step/gap between the validation set and training set, this new method has successfully evaluated the prediction performances including the formation energy algorithm (Fig. 12 a), band gap, and superconducting critical temperature of different materials. The functional-driven MAE (see Section 5.2) showed good chemical accuracy. Hyperparameters from cross-validation tests of MLA includes noise level λ and kernel parameter σ (Fig. 12b) [143]. It is hereby proved that errors of the method below 1 kcal/mol. Considering other degrees of freedom, the MLA tools still need to be applied in more complicated system. High-throughput screening has been widely used in the development of new materials [146,147], especially in the implementation of Material Genome Initiative (MGI). To date, several methods such as ML and data mining have been widely used in high throughput screening of materials [13]. With the help of MGI, ML can be used to mine the data of new reaction processes, new properties, or new structures. For example, high-throughput automated reaction screening and ML approaches have been introduced to mimic the interface reactions of solid electrolyte of lithium [144]. It has been well known that the solid electrolyte interface formed on Li metal surface will protect cells from Li-dendrites. The ML algorithms imply that the metal oxides control the interface reactions, where M-O bond enhance the stability of cation-doped solid electrolyte. The excellent correlation confirms the relationship of KRR predictions versus DFT values (Fig. 12c). This systematic study relies on the high-throughput screening of formation energy and interface reaction energy. Scalable and reproducible methods are welcome, since the difficulty of building heterogeneous junctions in experiments, especially maintaining specific components, morphology, and size distribution, limits the application in the field of catalysis and photovoltaics is limited. Schaak et al. [145] developed a cation-exchange reaction by using copper sulfide (Cu1.8S) as a template, which can synthesize more than 65,000 heterostructure nanorods in different lattice structures and interfaces (Fig. 12d). Due to the structural instability of the interface caused by the lattice mismatch, there may be unrealizable components in this heterostructure library. This high-throughput screening experiment cannot be verified by chemical synthesis in the laboratory. Fortunately, ML algorithms can do this kind of work. Currently, owing to the lack of mass failure data and experimental details, the ML method for high-throughput screening is far from meeting the requirements. Besides, the cost of high-throughput screening is still too expensive and it is time-consuming as well. More importantly, the knowledge of material properties is not comprehensive, particularly for new materials. Therefore, the deep integration of ML, high-throughput screening of advanced energy materials will promote its industry applications. 7 Conclusions and perspectives Based on knowledge of QC, ML algorithms seem to be a time-saving method to identify energy materials. Much attention on this field indicates a growing demand for multidisciplinary. From crystal identification of catalysts prediction, the complex chemical reaction descriptor can easily be summarized and trained in simple ML algorithms. This review highlights related studies using ML as a fast and accurate tool in energy material development. More chemists and computational scientists have focused on the development in this field: the knowledge gaps, future directions in machine learning research and applications in energy materials discovery and optimization [76]. Future researches should concentrate on the following interesting directions. Firstly, Researchers with a multidisciplinary background should focus on fundamental applications, especially the application of energy materials in the industrial field. Secondly, Open access database for high-throughput screening is urgently needed. Those inaccurate prediction results should not ascribe to algorithms but the lack of training data. Notably,Pan et al. [3] developed a material structure database and studied the bandgap of material structure by ML method. Thirdly, developing the technical databases for characterizing energy materials is important. Especially the relationship between different experimental results (database) needed to be established by using new techniques, such as X-ray absorption spectroscopy [85], neutron diffraction [86], transmission electron microscope [87], time-resolved computed tomography [148], spectroscopic X-ray nanoimaging [149] . Finally, more powerful algorithm needs to be used in new fields, for example, the reconstruction of imaging [67], identification of material structures [90], connection of structure-activity relationships [150,151] . There are still many important energy materials-related issues to explore assisted by ML, such as: (i) The efficient catalysts for nitrogen fixation reaction [152], (ii) catalytic efficiency of artificial photosynthesis [153], (iii) the degradation mechanism and life prediction of lithium-ion battery [154], (iv) prediction of key parameters for battery nail penetration test [155], and (v) agreed test criteria for flexible electronics and wearable devices [156]. All in all, high efficient/stable green energy materials need to be realized with the support of emerging artificial intelligence technologies. Baohua Li received his Ph.D. degree from the Institute of Coal Chemistry (ICC), Chinese Academy of Science (CAS) in 2002. He is currently a full professor and director of the Division of Energy and Environment of the Tsinghua Shenzhen International Graduate School, Tsinghua University. His research interest includes energy materials in the fields of new carbon materials, lithium-ion batteries, lithium-sulfur batteries, lithium-air batteries, supercapacitors, and fuel cells.

coredata.dc:description: In nature, the properties of matter are ultimately governed by the electronic structures. Quantum chemistry (QC) at electronic level matches well with a few simple physical assumptions in solving simple problems. To date, machine learning (ML) algorithm has been migrated to this field to simplify calculations and improve fidelity. This review introduces the basic information on universal electron structures of emerging energy materials and ML algorithms involved in the prediction of material properties. Then, the structure-property relationships based on ML algorithm and QC theory are reviewed. Especially, the summary of recently reported applications on classifying crystal structure, modeling electronic structure, optimizing experimental method, and predicting performance is provided. Last, an outlook on ML assisted QC calculation towards identifying emerging energy materials is also presented.
